All Reviews

  1. Light and creamy! Better than many higher priced products! Would recommend !
  2. I bought this moisturizer after hearing that Dr. Oz had recommended it, saying that it was the only moisturizer necessary...I assume because of the main ingredient, Collagen Elastin. I just finished the 10 oz. jar and while it does the job to hydrate my skin at night, I'm not sure about the long term benefits. Even though the manufacturer suggests day and night time use, I only use it at night since it doesn't have any SPF.
  3. I Have not had it long so we will see how it works
  4. Purchased off the reviews but can't really tell a difference from this and other face creams, smells nice though
  5. I was looking for an alternative to a very expensive facial lotion that I had been using. I saw that the rating on this product was very high and I have used some St. Ives products before (apricot scrub, body lotion) and they were fine. This product however is horrible-- I put it on the first day and I like the way it applied and absorbed. The second day was fine, too. The third day, however, I noticed the skin on my nose burned terribly when I applied the lotion. I was somewhat alarmed but the burning subsided and I forgot about it until that evening. I washed my face and the skin on my nose was rough, dry, and scaly. (I had this happen once before when I used a retinol product). I definitely have sensitive skin. Maybe if you don't, this product will be fine for you, but if you have any kind of sensitive skin avoid this product!
  6. I'm allergic to something in this product which sucks because it really does tighten things up.
  7. Wonderful moisturizer, Inexpensive and most importantly for me, cruelty free. I alternate it with a higher-end moisturizer for my aging skin. Nice scent, medium texture.
  8. I am not one to exaggerate, but I must say I love the St. Ives Timeless Skin Collagen Elastin facial moisturiser. The texture of the moisturizer is almost but not quite like a cream. I use daily and have noticed that my skin appears to be more even tone, slight reduction in fine lines. The most significant difference is the noticeably healthy glow that I now have. My skin does not look greasy at all, it looks dewy and fresh. The best part? I will be 50 years old in a few months!! Go St Ives!
  9. I really like this cream. It's very light and not greasy. I use it every morning under the makeup and at night after showering. It makes my face very soft and you can't beat the price. One jar lasts a long time....
  10. creamy and light moisturizer. You can use it on face and body. Very light on the skin. St Ives is a good value
  11. This lotion does a great job at keeping my skin looking in good condition! The product lasts forever as well. I bought the smaller jar and I still have plenty. I love that it does not have a strong smell and it doesn't make my face breakout. I have sensitive skin and some lotions can even cause my eyes to burn but this lotion does neither of those things. The only downside, is that its a little too thick for summer. I used it throughout winter and it did an amazing job but in the summer it gets a little sticky. I still use it as a night time cream but I have switched to a lighter cream for the day. I will stick with this product though as it is a such a great price and great product!
  12. Love it! Causes no irritation good for sensitive skin.
  13. I actually bought this at Walmart instead of Amazon. I might have paid maybe around 3 or 4 dollars for this TEN OUNCE jar. It's a lot of moisturizer, but it works fantastically. I am a serious skin care product junkie. My boyfriend likes to joke that if someone told me monkey poop would give me beautiful skin I'd be the first one in line to buy a tube. Curiously there have been no such studies. But St. Ives really outdid themselves with this one. I'm young, but I am a smoker...Terrible, even worse, because I know better. I started noticing deep lines forming down each sides of my face kind of between my nose and cheeks which I decided had to be because of this awful habit. Straight away I was on a mission to find some \\"cure\\" even after years of experimenting and using different skin care products and tools including vitamin E oil, hyaluronic acid, massage therapy, chemical peels, masks, face brushes, electronic face brushes, netted washclothes, etc. Now, I really liked the St. Ives Apricot scrub, but when I compared it to the cheaper Queen Helene version I was smitten. Having never tried any other St. Ives product, strangely, I shrugged off the entire line and figured it was just another dime a dozen commercial company with a \\"natural\\" gimmick. Now I see that I was missing out all this time on at least one of their gems, because I use this moisturizer every day faithfully and those lines have disappeared by 98%, not to mention my skin always looks hydrated, not greasy, oily, shiny or superficially moisturized at all. My skin texture appearance continues to improve with every use to the point that I always receive unsolicited compliments and I use foundation much more sparingly. This moisturizer really is very special... it just sinks into the skin and imparts the kind of suppleness we take for granted as children and then long for in adulthood. The smell is fresh and light.I even use it on my body sometimes! The formula is non-comedogenic, which is essential to someone like me with oily/combination skin type. The jar itself, while I anticipate battle cries among the nitpickers about hygiene risks, is extremely economical and will last forever. I could go on and on, but all anyone reading this needs to know is: PURCHASE IMMEDIATELY! I mean, come on ...the sheer number of reviews on this website alone should speak volumes!

  65. My family and I used to buy St Ives products in Margarita Island (tax free place), but due to control exchange and perhaps marketing issues they're not longer found in my country. Last year I ordered from Amazon a three-10 oz-jar offer of this cream, a bargain for the price, the jars size, and the better quality compared with other expensive brands I've tried. My mother and I shared the contents, and I even gave part of it to one of my sisters. After six months or more I'm just finishing my jar. But I've already ordered a new 10 oz jar last december, so I can keep using it without interruption. I have oily skin, and the texture of this cream is light and non-greasy, it absorbs very quickly and I love the smell (I've abandoned other creams because of their smell). I don't see any difference with the new formula. Both work nicely. I use it morning and night and my skin looks clearer, hydrated, smoother and I feel it more elastic. After some months using it everybody tells my face and neck look nicer. I do believe in the effects of this St Ives moisturizer, I love it. While I can keep on buying and using it, I will, and my mother will do as well!! I've also used other St Ives products now and in the past and I've never been disappointed. Actually I exfoliate my face weekly with St Ives Apricot Scrub Blemish&Blackhead Control, it removes dirty from my pores; immediately I put a more generous amount of St Ives Collagen Elastin face moisturizer and leave my face without any makeup at least for an hour or two.

And if you're worried about using it with breakouts/troubled skin, don't worry! I tend to break out very easily and have combination skin (oily t-zone, with patches of dry skin mixed in), and this moisturizer has not caused any breakouts or made my skin oily. Definitely give it a try!

  92. Moisturizing is very important for all ages. As a broke college student, I bought this as a cheap replacement for my more expensive Burt's Bees/Origins picks because I like more natural brands. It is certainly better than nothing and you get a lot more product than in most facial moisturizers, but I immediately noticed a difference in my skin -- and not a good one at that. Folks, you get what you pay for, if you are like me and you have to use this to get by, that's fine, but in the long run you should invest in your skin. I have gone back to using my Origins Night-A-Mins, and I think that all of the Burt's Bees moisturizers are quality as well if you don't want to spend big money (IMHO).

  97. Following the lead that Amazon prefers reviews of products other than books, music, films, etc and due to the increasing cold weather that seems to be sweeping the country this winter, this is another very fine product from St Ives. Coupled with the 24 hour advance moisturizer body lotion, this product is for use on the face and neck (it is also excellent for elbows!) as a means to protect the skin of the face form the drying effects of cold weather as well as the sagging effects of aging skin. The cream is easy to apply: no need for pads or sticks here, just scoop it out of the jar and massages into the entire face (except the eyes) and neck...not forgetting the ears. The recipe is apparently all natural - being derived form the essence of apricots, olives, minerals etc - so unless there is an allergic reaction to the fragrance used it should be safe for all skin types. As with most of the products from St. Ives is is immediately absorbed by the skin and does not leave a residuum on the surface that could be comedogenic. Important that it be used both day and night - day, for exposure to the elements, night to restore any damage incurred by the drying heat of the home. A very good product at a very reasonable price. Grady Harp, December 11
  98. This moisturizer is everything they say it is and more. I have been using this product for about 2 years now and it will always be a part of my daily regimen.

Even though my face feels greasy for a while, the lotion absorbs/dries nicely after a few minutes. I think it has a soothing, relaxing smell that is a nice way to end the day. My skin is sometimes dry, sometimes oily, super sensitive (even having SPF in a moisturizer will make my face break out), and always acne-prone (at least, until I started using this). Sometimes when I'm lazy or busy and don't take care of my skin for a week - don't wash my face before bed, etc. - and my skin breaks out, all I have to do is wipe my skin clean with a face wipe and then slather this stuff on at night for a day or two - and PRESTO my skin is back to being clear and smooth. Honestly it is a miracle for my skin. Also, I have lived in Seattle, Miami and Helena, Montana - so I have tested this in VASTLY different climates - and it has worked well for my skin in each city. It isn't heavy - I can put it on, wait three minutes, and put on foundation make-up without a problem. LOVE THIS STUFF! Cannot say enough good things about it.<br /><br />P.S.   251. This facial cream couldn't work better. I apply it once a day before bed, and it absorbs quickly. It is important to remember the difference between lotion and cream. Lotion (usually comes out of a pump bottle) sits on your skin, and absorbs minimally. Cream (like this St. Ives product) is water-based, and thus absorbs into your skin and moisturizes it much better. So I have always used creams. But with the collagen and elastin added into the cream, it makes it for a great anti-aging combo. And it is less than $4.00! I have been hearing that this product has a lot of mineral oil in it, and that mineral oil doesn't absorb into the skin or really do anything beneficial for you. Obviously, it is really cheap product and you get a lot of it. It's a good deal, but if it doesn't work, then what is the point? I will say that I use it as make-up remover, and that is works great for that! I also use it in the morning with sunscreen and wrinkle cream, so I'm using a lot of other products in conjunction with it. This is my second jar of it, so I did buy it again because I always thought that it did moisturize, but I think I may try another product after reading so many harsh reviews. Also I haven't seen any visible results in it reducing fine lines or wrinkles at all. I will finish the jar but browse other products when this product is gone because I'm not over the moon happy with it.

I won't contribute to pain and suffering, animal or human.<br /><br />There are many choices out there from companies that do not test on animals. My new way to go is to sign up for \\"The Body Shop\\" emails and stock up when they have a 40% sale. I like the company because they (a) oppose animal testing and (b) hold fundraisers to stop human trafficking.<br /><br />However, their lotions are a bit too expensive for me to get when they aren't on sale. But there are a number of other companies out there that oppose cruelty.<br /><br />I'm not a fan of some of PETA actions, but if you search for \\"PETA companies that don't test on animals,\\" they have a helpful webpage that will give you options.<br /><br />Summary: decent moisturizer, ineffective on lines, contributes to animal cruelty, going another way.

I am so pleased with this product. First off, there is what seems like an endless amount in the jar. Second, it smells so fresh. When you apply it your skin immediately looks dewy, rejuvenated, and feels wonderful. I'm glad I bought two jars! I've been using it for about a week so far and it does NOT make me breakout, if anything it may have helped.<br /><br />Happy moisturizing!

That's up to the individual, I guess - I love this stuff as an alternate when an AHA moisturizer becomes too irritating (can always tell by the extra redness in my face!) or, heck, when I'm too broke for a fancier cream. I find the St Ives to be silky and fast-absorbing. But what many people don't mention is this stuff is also AWESOME as a body lotion! I use it on my arms/hands/shoulders/d&eacute;colletage after a shower, and it quenches the skin, sinks in very fast, and leaves the skin looking healthy. At $4-5 bucks for a huge tub, it is absolutely worth having some of this around at all times!

  525. At less than $5 a jar, St. Ives Facial Moisturizer, Timeless Skin Collagen Elastin is quite a bargain. Using it occassionally on my face, nearly daily on my feet and after a month or so I have not hit the bottom of the jar yet.<br /><br />Be warned that the &#34;light&#34; fragrance is very strong when you initially open the container. I've noticed that the scent has faded (my smell sensitive daughter told me it &#34;doesn't stink so bad&#34; now) as the weeks have passed.<br /><br />My biggest complaint is that the cream is so slick that it slides off my fingers before I can get it on my skin. Surprisingly, it does not leave an oily residue, the scent quickly fades and even with my sensitive skin and mixing this with magnesium chloride oil does not break out my face, nor anywhere else I put it (feet! this plus mag oil has my feet looking and feeling a couple decades younger!)<br /><br />Decent product, great price, will probably reorder it as it works great on my feet and hands.
  526. it was quite nice but too oily for my skin in places
  527. I am absolutely amazed! I admit, I used this product for something other than my face. I had a baby 6 months ago. I had gained a LOT of weight during my pregnancy due to a medical condition that caused me to retain dangerous amounts of water. The skin on my stomach had stretched so bad during pregnancy my skin was not just stretching but tearing. It took me 6 weeks to loose all my weight, and I was left with horrifying loose skin on my tummy, literally I had am appointment scheduled with a laser center for July 20th because of my insecurity and my issue with this extra skin getting pinched in zippers, &#34;sorry for the gross details&#34; I decided to try this product on my stomach 2 weeks ago, because of my husbands strong objection to me going under a laser.. I can't believe the difference already. Not only is my skin very noticeably retracted, but my skins is as soft as my daughters!

  564. This product miosturized beautifully. However, I had a violent allergic reaction to the ingredient coumarin. I went to the emergency room one day because of pain shooting down my jaw, neck, and arms. I thought I was having a heart attack. This continued for months until I finally figured out that it was this face cream. Coumarin is a preservative that was outlawed in the USA by the FDA in 1954. It is used in perfumes, liqueurs, and some tobacco products. Think Jeffrey Wigand from &#34;The Insider&#34;. It is also used in rat poison. Be warned!

  575. I can't tell you how many face moisturizers I've used over the years. Lots. I still come across half full bottles in the closest or bathroom from three or four years ago, products that were too greasy, too thick, too irritating, too smelly, too watery, too expensive for such poor results. Ugg.<br /><br />But I do love St. Ives. I love their body lotions, hand lotions and masks, so when I came across this face moisturizing I was so excited. I searched for it in stores for a couple of weeks, and came away really disappointed. It seems like the only place you can buy this now is on the internet, and I'm thrilled that Amazon had such good prices. I spent around eight bucks for my 10 ounce jar, and a month into the use of it morning and night, I've barely made a dent!<br /><br />I'll be thirty this year, so I am taking preventative steps in my skin care routine now. Baby laugh lines, deep thinking lines and smile wrinkles are all visible (though my boyfriend says I'm the only one noticing at this point!). I am not ready to commit to heavy duty anti-wrinkle products yet, but I did want a product I could use daily that would give my skin a boast. This is that product!<br /><br />This moisturizer soaks in quickly. It has a light, floral scent (smells like other products that have safflower in it) and is white in color, with a smooth, solid-ish consistency. A lot goes a long way, and usually I just use some of what is on the lid of the jar, left there from jostling the jar around. I use it all over my face, neck and decolletage. I am careful to avoid my eye area though! This product is really, really NOT eye friendly, and that is the only drawback. The product warns to avoid the eye area, and that's no joke. I do use a separate moisturizer for my eyes anyway, and I usually apply that first so I have a good idea of where to put the face cream afterwards. A little warm water or witch hazel can calm any eye contact though.<br /><br />After a month I am really content with this moisturizer. It does not make my skin overly oily, it does not irritate my skin -- though it does bother my eyes if I get it in or near them -- and it soaks in fast, so I don't have to delay putting on make in the morning, or laying down on my pillow at night.<br /><br />While I haven't seen over the top, super results as far as my little wrinkles go, I do know my skin is consistently moisturized, more even in tone, softer and yes -- a little bit firmer. I also love that I can layer other things on top (like a primer, sunscreen or powder) without my skin getting clogged and gross.<br /><br />Over all I am really pleased with this product, and it is now a staple in my skin care routine. I'll definitely be buying this when I run out...in about four or five months! Ten ounces is a lot!<br /><br />-JR-moisturizer. It does not make my skin overly oily, it does not irritate my skin -- though it does bother my eyes if I get it in or near them -- and it soaks in fast, so I don't have to delay putting on make in the morning, or laying down on my pillow at night.<br /><br />While I haven't seen over the top, super results as far as my little wrinkles go, I do know my skin is consistently moisturized, more even in tone, softer and yes -- a little bit firmer. I also love that I can layer other things on top (like a primer, sunscreen or powder) without my skin getting clogged and gross.<br /><br />Over all I am really pleased with this product, and it is now a staple in my skin care routine. I'll definitely be buying this when I run out...in about four or five months! Ten ounces is a lot!<br /><br />-JR-

  594. I have skin which is prone to breakouts and after a few trials with different products I settled with my current pond's cream, which I have been using for past three years as a night time moisturizer. It's like that ideal feel of neither dry nor oily, just perfectly smooth and soft skin (It feels almost as soft as my 3 years old's skin). I am in my early 30s and don't really need a fine line remover as of now so not concerned about that aspect. As long as St. Ives keeps my facial moister balanced I will keep on using it. I can say that my skin feels smoother, but a true collagen rebuilder is usually taken orally, through supplements or the right foods. For example eating a lot of oranges or taking a vitamin C supplement would help rebuild collagen. Some people actually cut thin slices of oranges and put them on their face! I’m not much for that because of the way it feels, but I wanted to just state that I’m not 100% sure how much collagen you can get form a topical cream.<br /><br />That said, I still like it and I love St. Ives’ philosophy. So go ahead and buy it!

One of the reviews mentioned that it's not oil-free which is true but not all oils are bad. For example, jojoba oil is not comedogenic AT ALL, but it doesn't absorb well and just sits on your face. You can't go out with it because it looks like you have olive oil on your face and you can't use it at night because it all ends up on the pillow. This moisturizer absorbs really well and the oil that it contains (mineral oil) does not cause acne.

  712. I'm a man, who has naturally smooth, typically blemish free skin. My entire skin care regiment has basically consisted of a good soap and water scrub in the shower with my wash cloth, and that's that. My skin has never felt like it was in need of a moisturizer, and after a regular old shower wash it feels pretty good, or \\"dewy\\" as my wife likes to call it. But I'm also an actor, and I'm 31 years old now. I drink a lot of water (when I don't I can tell the difference), I don't smoke, and I rarely drink, but I've also started looking around for skin care products that will help me preserve the quality of my skin, and keep me as fresh and youthful looking as possible. For me it's not an issue of vanity, but of actual livelihood; how my skin looks has actual career and financial implications. Having good skin isn't an excuse for me to just assume I'll always have good skin, and I've heard enough times by now that starting younger is better. Back in the day my sister and mom use to use the old St. Ives apricot scrub, which I used a few times many years ago. You know the one that basically felt you were scrubbing your face with gravel. I liked the rougher texture, and decided to turn to try St. Ives now when I was looking for some skin care products. After reading reviews for several, I ultimately decided on the extremely well regarded [[ASIN:B0017MO8AS St. Ives Timeless Skin Daily Microdermabrasion 4 oz (113 g)]]and this moisturizer. Last night I used both for the first time. While I'm looking to take better care of my skin, I also am not looking to use a 1,000 products, or have a lot of fuss and work over my skin. The exfoliating cream was a lot less harsh than I expected, especially in comparison to the old apricot scrub. I used that, let me skin dry a little, and then applied the moisturizer. Now like I said above, I'm use to \\"dewy\\" skin naturally. But about 10 minutes after applying this stuff I was literally floored at how my skin felt. My skin feels better than I have ever felt it in my life. It's extremely smooth, feels taut, and looks vibrant and bright. I don't have a ton of experience with a wide variety of skin care products, so I have no idea if this is standard, but none of the products I have used even remotely came close to making my skin feel, and look, this amazing. My wife came home and I told her she had to touch my face, and she did. She said it felt really \\"firm\\", almost like I'd had botox or something (which I thought was hilarious). She couldn't stop rubbing her arm on my face, just to feel the texture. I think she was a little jealous ;). It's over 12 hours since I put this stuff on and my skin still feels like a satin sheet. I've never written a review for a skin care product. I never imagined I would even be compelled to. But I'm telling you, especially you reluctant men out there, this stuff feels insanely good on your skin. Between this, and the other product, I've found something quick, easy, and most importantly, something that worked from the FIRST application.
  713. I have tried literally everything for my sensitive skin. This absorbs quickly but leaves the skin firm and with no oily residue. This works really well and I feel I've gotten results with only two weeks of use so far.

  786. I've been using this product for probably 20 years, and I'm now 64. I wouldn't say it's a miracle potion, but my facial skin is mostly wrinkle-free and looks healthy--and I only apply it about every other day.<br /><br />FYI, Unilever, one of the consumer product megacorps, now owns St. Ives, and this product has changed. I happen to have an old pre-Unilever jar which states the product is not tested on animals, but the other day, when I bought a new jar at a local pharmacy, I noticed that that claim was gone and there was a Unilever logo in the corner. So I emailed Unilever asking if the product had been tested on animals, and their response was a link to a web page that contained an awful lot of PR BS about how they're trying to evolve into a non-animal testing company, blah blah blah. But no specific information about this moisturizer was offered.<br /><br />I compared the ingredients in the old jar to the new one, and I noticed that at least three of the natural ingredients are now missing and the order of ingredients has been shuffled. So for any of you who are experiencing skin irritation, there may be good reason for that. It's not the same product it used to be. Beware. I'm returning my jar to the store I bought it at and I'll be looking for an animal-kind moisturizer to replace it.<br /><br />Please consider writing your representative in Congress to co-sponsor the Humane Cosmetics Act. The E.U., Israel, Norway, and India have already banned the inhumane and unscientific practice of animal testing on cosmetics. More accurate results can be obtained from human-based cell and tissue testing methods.<br /><br />If you want more information on cruelty-free cosmetics, check out, on the NEAVS (New England Anti-Vivisection Society) website, the Coalition for Consumer Information on Cosmetics (CCIC), which certifies more than 500 brands that do not test on animals. Another excellent source is Cruelty Free International, which is a global campaign to end animal testing (more information on NEAVS website). You can watch the video by Ricky Gervais and read about actor Peter Dinklage's association with this campaign.<br /><br />And did you know that besides being unethical, animal testing produces severe environmental pollution? Find out the shocking facts on the NEAVS website under environmental campaigns.<br /><br />Here's a listing of the ingredients in my pre-Unilever moisturizer. You can compare it to the Unilever ingredients (including the changed order) and make up your own mind about it:<br /><br />Water--Mineral oil<br />Propylene glycol<br />PEG-100 stearate<br />Glycerol stearate<br />Stearic acid<br />Phenoxyethanol<br />Carthamus tinctorius (safflower seed) oil<br />Triethanolamine<br />Carbomer<br />Dimethicone<br />Cetyl alcohol<br />Disodium EDTA<br />Fragrance<br />Ethylhexylglycerin<br />Linalool<br />Hexyl cinnamol<br />Hydrolyzed elastin<br />Hydrolyzed collagen<br />Coumarin<br />Geraniol<br /><br />.bsite). You can watch the video by Ricky Gervais and read about actor Peter Dinklage's association with this campaign. And did you know that besides being unethical, animal testing produces severe environmental pollution? Find out the shocking facts on the NEAVS website under environmental campaigns. Here's a listing of the ingredients in my pre-Unilever moisturizer. You can compare it to the Unilever ingredients (including the changed order) and make up your own mind about it: Water--Mineral oil Propylene glycol PEG-100 stearate Glycerol stearate Stearic acid Phenoxyethanol Carthamus tinctorius (safflower seed) oil Triethanolamine Carbomer Dimethicone Cetyl alcohol Disodium EDTA Fragrance Ethylhexylglycerin Linalool Hexyl cinnamol Hydrolyzed elastin Hydrolyzed collagen Coumarin Geraniol .

  800. I had been using a facial cream that cost $24.95 a jar but found myself suddenly allergic to it.   857. Unilever was instrumental in destroying the original all natural Pears glycerin soap of 1807, not only by removing the natural herbal scents but also by adding a plethora of chemicals to the formula. Pears has now been discontinued entirely! Since they bought out Alberto Culver, they have been slowly downgrading all of the St Ives skin products I used. Beware of the new Timeless Skin Collagen Elastin formula which contains Linalool, It is narcotic and creates respiratory disturbances. It attracts bees. It causes CNS disorder. It is toxic to animals. As well as Cinnamal which can cause skin irritation. Their new Pears formula, which contained both of these ingredients, gave me an itchy rash! In fact, I suggest you check all your personal skin and hair products and avoid any containing these ingredients, which are showing up more and more lately in everything! Seems like large conglomerates are moving backwards to obtain more profits in spite of knowing better about harmful chemicals and we are letting them and potentially harming ourselves and our planet by buying and using these products. However, it is becoming harder and harder to find affordable alternatives. Guess we need to complain to the FDA instead of the manufacturers and get more of these harmful ingredients banned.

This product applies smoothly and effortlessly without any stinging, harsh fragrance, or chemical dependency. My face absolutely loves the stuff. I use this in the morning, at night, and sometimes mid-day, dependent upon the state of my skin - Accutane side effects do not always follow your schedule. I have been using this in this manner diligently for two months and still have over half the jar left. I have virtually no flaking and my skin continues to feel supple and hydrated throughout the day. This also works as a great primer for makeup. Lately i've noticed that the skin around my eyes sometimes gets very dry, sensitive, and sometimes red and irritated. I have not been able to figure out if this is from the moisturizer itself, the oil i add to it, or some other outside factor, as i use the combination on a daily basis and the irritation only occurs from time to time. I have since bought a new natural vitamin E facial moisturizer that i'm going to try, but i keep this stuff tucked away just because it's a fair deal. It's great for when you're in a pinch. I've never used anything, expensive department store brand to drugstore brands, that has made such a good impression on me as this particular St. Ives moisturizer. To give you an idea of my routine and skin type: I wash my face, exfoliate (3-4 times/week), then moisturize. This is important because no matter what moisturizer you use, you must have clean, exfoliated skin to maximize any kind of good result. My skin is a combination of dry and oily. I started having trouble with fine lines (33 yrs. old) about a year ago.<br /><br />The first thing I noticed about the moisturizer when I opened the tub is it's consistency. It forms stiff peaks like whipped cream and is as smooth as silk. Not too watery, not too thick. Perfect.<br /><br />As a previous reviewer (E.D.Head) said so well, \\"The minute you apply this it is a part of your skin.\\" It sinks in with long lasting softness and zero greasy feel. It maintains the balance of my combination skin well. A little goes a long way.<br /><br />It is pleasantly and lightly scented. Great when your nose is right there to smell what you're rubbing in on and around it. It didn't trigger my allergies, either.<br /><br />As for my fine lines, I haven't been using it long enough to know whether it will diminish them. However, with my skin looking so healthy, the lines look healthier, too. HA - I've got healthy lines on my face vs. unhealthy. I don't know any other way to describe it, but they are somehow better. Try this and see for yourself.<br /><br />Bonus: My fingers that I use to apply this with felt so much better than the rest of my hands with which I use Aveeno body lotion. I could tell where the St. Ives moisturizer had sunk in and where it didn't felt so much worse. So now I use a little extra to rub into my hands when I'm done. What a difference. Having nice hands is a bonus!<br /><br />This product is a keeper and I highly recommend it.
  921. I'm a 28 year old male, with thin, sensitive skin. My complexion is clear and mostly smooth with larger pores on my cheeks on either side of my nose. In warmer months, I have normal to oily skin and, in colder months, I have tight, dry skin, especially around my chin, nose, and forehead. I am a smoker. When I turned 18, I had my first major experience with dry skin. At the time, I was bathing with a bar of soap, including my face. I developed a red, flaky rash around my chin and upper lip that winter, which was embarrassing. I had no idea why it occurred and went to the doctor, who prescribed antibiotics and steroids which did very little. In fact, using the steroids for more than a few weeks caused steroid induced dermatitis everywhere it had been applied. I began using Spectro Jel and then Cetaphil exclusively on my face (and body wash to bathe), and the rash faded and never returned. Within the last couple of years, I've simply been using a sensitive skin body wash tailored for my body and face with no problems - usually either Dove Men or Nivea. Still, every winter, I develop tight, dry skin, which is mildly flaky (but not rashy, like before) around my chin, nostrils, and between my eyebrows. The creases around my nostrils and upper lip also become slightly red, like wind burn. I decided to try a moisturizer with some reluctance because I've always been afraid that adding anything to my face that isn't a cleanser will cause a break out. I've had bad luck in the past with moisturizers doing this and ultimately why I swore them off for years. Sensitive skin is a gift and a curse. On one hand, my skin is very soft and smoothly textured; on the other, it's hard to balance the need to cleanse to prevent blemishes and the need to moisturize so dry skin doesn't occur. I bought this product based on reviews, which is always a gamble. So far, I am very satisfied. The moisturizer is light and once it goes on it does not feel heavy on the face. The odoris slightly medicinal but does not linger when applied. My face is feeling moisturized and supple. Problem areas, especially the outsides of my nostrils which are always the tightest, are no longer dry, tight, and flaky. I haven't experienced any reddening, either. No blemishes so far - I have been applying the moisturizer for the past 4-5 days. Even the creases on either side of my mouth seem filled in and smooth - I always thought &#34;fine line repair&#34; was advertising fluff for older, wrinkly women wanting to look young again. I will update in the future. So far, so good. **Update - 5/6/15** I have unfortunately downgraded my rating to three stars. I used the moisturizer sporadically over this past winter. The honeymoon period - when I made my original 5-star review - quickly wore off. While this product does moisturize well, it started to cause blemishes for me, even with light use. It does not irritate my skin but it clearly clogs my pores. So, for those with oily or combo skin and prone to blemishes, I would not recommend this.

  967. These ingredients are sooooooo TOXIC. I would never put this poison on my face. It is full of petroleum based ingredients. Phenoxyethanol is banned in Europe and is a central nervous system depressant. Propylene Glycol is related to Anti-freeze. Dimethicone is also petroleum based. Fragrances (parfums) are unknown synthetic chemicals. Linalool is a skin irritant. I mean, why don't we just go to the gas station and splash motor oil all over our bodies? There are so many toxic ingredients in this it would take an hour to go over all of this. Please, women, educate yourselves. Go to EWG SkinDeep to research ingredients. Don't buy toxic skincare products.

  974. Ugh. I can't stand it when products claim to be full of beneficial ingredients, but when you look at the ingredients list, those things are only barely there. There is only a very tiny amount of collagen and elastin in this product -- certainly not enough to really cause any significant changes in one's skin. If you look at the ingredients list, the Hydrolyzed Elastin and Hydrolyzed Collagen are listed as the 18th and 19th ingredients. The main ingredient in this is mineral oil, which will definitely moisturize your skin but isn't necessarily GOOD for your skin, because it forms a film on the surface of your skin that can not be absorbed, thereby blocking the pores and the skin's natural respiration.

  992. Collagen Elastin, good stuff, but mineral oil is one of the worst if not the worst oil for your skin. If the company had used a natural oil, like coconut, olive, almond oil this would have been a great product but not mineral oil. Research mineral oil. Bad stuff. Surprised this product got such good reviews. Mineral oil does not allow the skin to breath, it increases the photo aging of skin, It dissolves your skins natural oils which causes the skin to become more dehydrated. Mineral oil is petroleum based, synthetic oil. Once it is absorbed it is broken down in the liver and intestinal tracts where it steals valuable vitamins from the body which will not be replaced. So this is bad stuff, stick to natural oils.

She told me last night that she is using it all over and that her skin looks awesome and feels like it did 20 yrs. ago, so I started trying it all over too! Folks this stuff is the best and believe me I have tried all that is out there and I have never had results like this ever!! I LOVE St Ives so this is not a slam piece at all, this face moisturizer is just not of any kind of quality. First the ingredients in this cream suck, there is not 1 positive ingredient in this mess. If you want to say collage and elastin work for the skin then you can, but they don't. It is impossible for those molecules to penetrate the skins surface. The only way to fix a collage issue is to eat better, to eat foods that help produce collagen and protect the skin. Secondly, mineral oil is the second ingredient, this is a no-no for most people. I am assuming this is what made me break out like a teenager. Lastly, it is not moisturizing nor does it embody any vitamins that have been actually shown to improve ones skin. This is the first St. Ives product I have had an adverse reaction to but since Unileaver bought them I am sure there will be more upsetting formulas and formula changes to come.

  1116. When I first noticed this unfamiliar, bulky jar sold for a few bucks at the drugstore, I assumed it was cheap quality. After all, it didn't even have sun protection.<br /><br />That was until I saw it on my friend's makeup counter. The friend with perfect skin, who is also very picky about her products and has tried many high end moisturizers before. She claims this one was a winner at a great value, and points out that sunscreen can be easily added using strong spf makeup. So, I decided to try it.<br /><br />It's been almost a month now, and my skin is in love with this stuff. It has a light, pleasant fragrance that is probably due to the exclusion of SPF. It applies smoothly despite the semi gel texture. At night, I apply this all over my face and neck, and it gives me a healthy glow in the morning. In the morning, I apply this under my spf BB cream and spf foundation, and it does not mess with the makeup at all. It's winter and I have not seen a single trace of flaking skin (which was a huge problem every other year). I have no wrinkles and do not use it for the collagen boost. However, it is a great facial moisturizer and you get tons of product for the price.<br /><br />I hate the packaging. It does not even come with a scoop and becomes very unhygienic to use. My recommendation is to scoop some of the brand new product into a tiny travel sized jars and use those on a daily basis. This prevents contamination of the entire tub.

  1208. My face has never felt softer. I've only been using it for a couple of weeks so I'm not sure if I can speak to the results yet, but i'm loving it!
  1209. I'm not sure if this really works as a skin tightener but it's a great moisturizer and is cheaper than what I used to buy but works just as well. It's lightweight but still feels very moisturizing.

  1216. St. Ives is a good product - especially for the price. This is a light, sheer moisturizer good for normal, combination or oily younger skin. It works as a protective day moisturizer for normal skin that can get a little soiled from daily activities. It does not have enough moisture for dry skin. It has a delicate, very light, pleasing fragrance. Soon after application I forget I have it on. I like it very much for a day moisturizer or for hands and feet at night. Don't expect reparative results. Collagen doesn't soak into deep layers of the skin - certainly not in this formula. It would need a micro delivery system, and it is still debatable whether it can truly benefit the skin. In that case you would be better off to go with a different reparative product. I worked with a woman once that has been in cosmetics at Nieman Marcus for 150 years. :*) She says, &#34;If she didn't get her skin care for free, she would use St. Ives.&#34; Not a bad recommendation there. For the price I give it 5 for sure.

  1311. Like many other reviewers, I had read that this was a great facial moisturizer to replace pricier products. My skin is \\"normal,\\" as in, it's not too sensitive, not too dry, not too oily, just... normal. In the cooler months, my skin tends to dry out a bit, so I look for a heavier moisturizer at night. I'm in my late 20s and have always taken care of my skin, so I'm mostly looking for moisture without grease, and to take care of the faintest of fine lines.<br /><br />That being said, this is horrible on my face. It goes on greasy, which, fine, I'll wear it as a night cream. However, it completely dried out the skin around my nose, under my eyes, and most of my cheeks. I hadn't changed anything else about my skin routine, so I know it was this, and it happened on the first night. I used it for four more days and nights in the hopes that my skin would get used to it. Nope! My skin is still dry and flaky in those areas. I started using a different moisturizer and my skin is now much smoother and softer.<br /><br />Another reviewer mentioned that this cream was great for her stretch marks. I'm six months post-partum and have awful stretch marks on my stomach; after just five days, my skin there is so much smoother and the marks have obviously lightened.   1342. Alright, so considering all the wonderful reviews this product has, and the price, I thought it was too good to be true. However, at the price, who could say no? Not me, definitely.<br /><br />The delivery was awesome, I must say. It arrived within two days, with standard shipping. I was very impressed.<br />First impressions of the product: It's quite thick, when applied to hands it absorbs very quickly.<br />Now, my skin somehow manages to be simultaniously ver dry, and oily enough to be shiny if I don't do anything about it. I'm also still young enough to have hormonal acne, so I need to choose my products very carefully. My first night using this moisturizer, I put on my usual amount, by dipping clean fingers into the jar then smoothing it over my face. I found that while it absorbed very quickly, after about ten minutes the previously matte look it left on my face turned oily--and glistening. I decided to try it anyway, and when I woke up in the morning I was totally broken out. I then decided to try using less, and found that when only applying a very small amount, it worked perfectly. However, the small amount wasn't enough to keep my dry skin hydrated, and any more would have had me breaking out.<br />IMPORTANT TO NOTE:<br />Based on my own experiences, I feel this product should and will work very well for someone who DOESN'T have crazy combination skin like mine, i.e. if your skin is very dry, put on more, or oily--less. Remember that if your skin is dry in some areas but oily in others (normal combination skin) than you should apply different amounts to those areas accordingly.<br />OVERALL:<br />I thought this was a very good product, but was still rather disappointed that it didn't work for me, personally. However, at the price, it can't be beat. Unless you have skin like mine, I absolutely recommend it.

  1407. I had heard about this moisturizer before on Pintrest being supported by Dr. Oz for its benefits, and so I decided to look into it. My skin is combo/oily where my T-zone gets horribly oily within a few hours and my cheeks can sport dry, flaky patches, so finding a good night-time moisturizer that wouldn't tip my skin's delicate balance was crucial. For a while I was using Aveeno's or Generic Aveeno night-time cream, but the expense was getting to be too much. As much as I love Aveeno, their face products can get pretty pricey. So when I heard about a St. Ive's face cream that supposedly worked better than the more expensive brands, I was definitely intrigued. Since I've used St. Ives exfoliating cleansers for my skin to treat acne, I had a good feeling about this product.<br /><br />The first night I tried it, my skin literally drank the cream in. I was surprise at how much it took in, like it was dehydrated. Luckily, after the first few nights, I didn't need so much for my skin to feel adequately moisturized. Once my skin acclimated, I must say, my skin visibly looked smoother and softer, it felt honestly healthier than it had in weeks before. The dry patches disappeared, the oil problem stopped being so bad at night (although I found other ways to treat it during the day), and the skin of my neck became softer and smoother as well. This product pretty much exceeded my expectations, not only in terms of performance, but also in terms of price and amount. For less than six dollars, I got so much product that even after the last month, I've made only the slightest dent in the amount of product in the tub.<br /><br />But one of my favorite things about this product is the scent. Yes, it does have a mild scent, but one that definitely isn't overpowering or irritating. To me, it honestly smells like fresh cut Golden Delicious apples. It's bizarre but true! I love the scent! It's very mild and only noticeable when you start putting it on and rubbing it in, but the scent quickly dissipates, so no lingering smell if you don't like it. But I love that little quirk.<br /><br />I would definitely recommend this to others. It's cheap for the amount, sinks into the skin so easily without any greasy residue, honestly works as my skin looks so much better after having been using it for over a month now, and the scent is delicious. Five stars all the way!quickly dissipates, so no lingering smell if you don't like it. But I love that little quirk.<br /><br />I would definitely recommend this to others. It's cheap for the amount, sinks into the skin so easily without any greasy residue, honestly works as my skin looks so much better after having been using it for over a month now, and the scent is delicious.   1493. I've been using St Ives Timeless Skin moisturizer for a long time and I am very happy with it. It works beautifully for my combination skin, hydrating my dry areas and yet light enough to not add shine or oil to my oily t-zone. I like that it has clean, safe ingredients too - I noticed a few reviews from people complaining about certain ingredients and spreading false info. I've personally researched every ingredient in this moisturizer (as I do every product I put on my skin or in my body), and I just felt I should set the record straight.<br /><br />(1) Cosmetic and pharmacological grade mineral oil is completely different from industrial mineral oil (which is what many people try to scare you with). It is highly refined to allow skin to breathe while at the same time creating a protective barrier on skin, locking in moisture. It is one of the safest, most effective and most gentle moisturizers known to man. It does not cause cancer, damage your liver or age skin - all those claims are from misinformed people who confuse it with unrefined industrial mineral oil. The two are totally different.<br /><br />(2) Propylene Glycol is a humectant and delivery agent. It is very safe and used in minuscule amounts in cosmetic products. It helps bring the active ingredients in a product down deep into the skin where they can be utilized for the skin's benefit.<br /><br />I am more than a little tired of the scare tactics used by some overzealous but misinformed people about perfectly safe ingredients. People, please don't listen to every scary person or website, but do your own research. Consider valid, medical affiliated websites with actual accountability and peer reviewed information, NOT the websites that are more like blogs by fear-mongers, or websites designed to sell their own &#34;natural&#34; products. Such websites can be biased and can leave YOU misinformed about the truth. Honestly, there are people out there that will tell you just about anything you can think ofis bad for your health. Use your own brain and do your own research.<br /><br />I've been using this Timeless face cream for years and I believe it has contributed to my skin staying young looking, smooth and soft. I also use a foundation with SPF everyday, even in winter. Having said that, just FYI, I am 41 years old and sometimes still get carded (not often, but hey, the fact that it happens at all at my age is really good! I'll take it!). So ... That's my 2 cents. Hope it helps!<br /><br />:)

I bought this product a few days ago at a drug store and it's completely (sort of) different. Keep in mind, I am reading straight from my jar and typing this so there can be some typing errors and/or shortenings.<br /><br />Ingredients: Water, Mineral Oil, Propylene Glycol, Glyceryl Stearate, PEG-100 Stearate, Stearic Acid, [Safflower] Seed Oil, Hydrolyzed Collagen, Hydrolyzed Elastin, Triethanolamine, Carbomer, Cetyl Alcohol, Dimethicane, Disodium EDTA, Ethylhexylglycerin, Phenoxyethanol, Fragrance<br /><br />You can search up any of these listed, which I did, and I found that most of them were oils or other organic compounds to help the oils become more soluble.

  1604. This product is NOT non-comedogenic - or at least, it hasn't been for me. I have very clear skin and rarely have breakouts - yet after 2 or 3 nights in a row of applying this, I break out. At first I thought the break-outs were hormonally related, but I stopped using this moisturizer and went back to a vitamin A cream I had been using before, and the acne went away entire. I waited another month, and tried going back to this cream - sure enough, acne.<br /><br />What's worse, the stuff is apparently just greasy enough that it causes mini-cysts for me. I thought the little breakouts might go away after my skin adjusted to using this for awhile... but then, after 2-3 weeks, I developed little hard white bumps on my skin that didn't go away even after stopping use of this moisturizer - and mini-cysts take a looooong time to clear up on their own. I ended up going to a dermatologist and had to get a $30 prescription to clear them up.<br /><br />Fast forward to 10 months later, and I found my still-almost-full jar of St. Ives facial moisturizer. 'Maybe I was been imagining all the acne, and the cysts must have been caused by something else...' I thought, so I decided to give this another try... Long story short, good thing I have some of that prescription left, because a cyst popped back up within a week, and acne to boot.<br /><br />Guess this stuff is going to have to be demoted to a hand moisturizer and I'll hope it doesn't clog my pores there too. It's a shame, too - this is a value-priced jar of product that was highly rated and very popular on Amazon, so I had such high hopes...
